instruction: How was the machine learning model trained and tested in the related study that combines drone and satellite images to produce landscape-scale maps of flowering dynamics in forest ecosystems?

The machine learning model in the related study was trained and tested using data from multiple sites and various dates throughout the flowering season of the eucalypt Corymbia calophylla. The training data consisted of drone-derived images of flowering eucalypt canopies, which were used to label satellite image pixels with the proportion of a pixel footprint that is flowering. These labeled pixels, representing the response variable, were then combined with various metrics characterizing time series of spectral indices sensitive to the presence of green vegetation and cream-colored flowers, which served as the predictor variables.

The model was trained with data from two sites, where the drone-derived images and corresponding satellite images were available. The model learned the relationship between the predictor variables and the labeled flowering proportions at the pixel level. The training process involved optimizing the model's parameters to minimize the difference between the predicted flowering proportions and the actual labeled proportions in the training data.

After training, the model was tested using data from three additional sites and various dates within the Corymbia calophylla flowering season. The model's performance was evaluated by comparing the predicted flowering proportions with the actual labeled proportions in the testing data. The root mean square error (RMSE) was calculated to assess the accuracy of the model's predictions.
